0	0	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-clinton-emails-idUSKCN0YV2P3	Emails in Clinton probe dealt with planned drone strikes: WSJ	"

WASHINGTON Emails between U.S. diplomats in Islamabad and State Department officials in Washington about whether to challenge specific U.S. drone strikes in Pakistan are at the center of a criminal probe involving Hillary Clinton's handling of classified information
column2: the Wall Street Journal reported on Thursday.The 2011 and 2012 emails were sent via the ""low side"" -government slang for a computer system for unclassified matters - as part of a secret arrangement that gave the State Department more of a voice in whether a CIA drone strike went ahead
column3: according to congressional and law enforcement officials briefed on the FBI probe
column4: the Journal said.Some of the emails were then forwarded by Clinton's aides to her personal email account
column5: which routed them to a server she kept at her home in suburban New York when she was secretary of state
column7: according to the newspaper.Investigators have raised concerns that Clinton's personal server was less secure than State Department systems
column8: and a recent report by the State Department inspector general found that Clinton had broken government rules by using a private email server without approval
column9: undermining Clinton's earlier defenses of her emails.   The still-secret emails are a key part of the FBI investigation that has long dogged Clinton's presidential campaign

column1: Clinton this week clinched the Democratic presidential nomination for the Nov. 8 election and was endorsed by President Barack Obama on Thursday.The White House rebuffed questions by reporters on Thursday on whether Obama's endorsement might be seen as unduly influencing a criminal investigation by the U.S. Justice Department involving Clinton.

White House spokesman Josh Earnest told reporters that Obama ""has reiterated his commitment to this principle that any criminal investigation should be conducted independent of any sort of political interference.""The emails
column2: which did not mention the ""CIA
column3: ""drones"" or details about the militant targets
column4: were written within the often-narrow time frame in which State Department officials had to decide whether or not to object to drone strikes before the CIA pulled the trigger

column1: Law enforcement and intelligence officials said State Department deliberations about the covert CIA drone program should have been conducted over a more secure government computer system designed to handle classified information
column2: the Journal reported. (Writing by Eric Beech; Additional reporting by Jonathan Allen in New York; Editing by Peter Cooney)"	['Allen'

column1: 2	2	http://reuters.com/article/us-alaska-ratings-idUSKCN0YW01E	S&P ratchets up pressure on Alaska over budget	"
By Rory Carroll

S&P Global Ratings warned on Thursday that the credit rating for key Alaska bonds could go down if lawmakers fail to agree on a budget that addresses the state's long term-fiscal problems. Alaska Governor Bill Walker convened a special session of the legislature late last month aimed at passing a budget for fiscal 2017 and closing the state's nearly $4 billion deficit
column2: which has been driven by a collapse in global oil prices. S&P on Thursday put the state's AA-plus general obligation
column3: AA appropriation
column4: and A-plus moral obligation ratings on Alaska's debt on CreditWatch with negative implications. The bond proceeds are expected to pay for several transportation-related projects.

column1: The CreditWatch placement indicates that we may lower Alaska's credit rating if state policymakers defer adopting fiscal reforms to correct the state's structural budget deficit
column2: said Gabriel Petek
column3: a S&P Global Ratings credit analyst. Since the special session began late last month the legislature has passed a $4.4 billion spending plan for fiscal 2017 and a bill to reduce the cost of the state's oil and gas tax credit program
column4: S&P said.

column1: But it is unclear if a hotly contested bill that would transfer money from the state's permanent fund to its general fund will overcome opposition in the state House of Representatives. The bill
column2: SB 128
column3: would reduce the amount paid out to residents annually from the fund.Even if it passes
column4: S&P said it remains to be seen whether SB 128 and other fiscal reforms would be sufficient to put Alaska's fiscal structure on a sustainable trajectory.

column1: Enactment of SB 128 alone would shrink the deficit
column2: but it wouldn't eliminate it. In order to fully close the structural fiscal gap
column3: other measures - such as new income tax or more spending cuts - would also be necessary
column4: S&P said. Despite the budget deficit
column5: S&P said Alaska continues to have very strong credit quality due to the large reserves it built up over times when oil prices were high.  (Reporting by Rory Carroll in San Francisco; Editing by Matthew Lewis)"	[]	[]

column1: 3	3	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-congress-paytv-idUSKCN0YV23G	U.S. Congress scrutinizes pay TV billing
column2: competitive practices	"

column1: By David Shepardson
| WASHINGTON

WASHINGTON A U.S. Senate panel disclosed Thursday it is investigating pay TV competition and customer service issues and will call executives from top cable and satellite providers to testify.The investigation comes as the U.S. cable and satellite TV industry ranks among the lowest in consumer surveys over billing and other practices. Senators Rob Portman
column2: an Ohio Republican who chairs a panel on investigations and Claire McCaskill
column3: a Missouri Democrat
column4: said in a statement Thursday that they will hold a June 23 hearing that will include testimony from Comcast Corp
column7: a unit of AT&T Inc and Dish Network Corp.The pair said in a joint statement the panel has been investigating the largest cable and satellite TV companies for more than a year
column8: looking at potential barriers to competition in the industry
column9: ""including the difficulties faced by companies attempting to create innovative new television delivery models."" The committee has also been examining billing
column11: refunds and other customer service issues.

column1: We believe our hearing will be a big step forward for consumers
column2: allowing them to understand how their TV providers really work and make informed decisions about their video service
column3: the pair said. Comcast declined to comment. Charter
column4: which completed its acquisition of Time Warner Cable and Bright House Networks in May
column5: said in a statement ""our overall customer satisfaction ratings are trending in the right direction. Call volume into our call centers is declining

column1: The senators noted that a recent American Customer Satisfaction Index survey found pay television service ranked near the bottom of the 43 industries surveyed - a year after the pay-TV industry tied for the lowest score among all industries ranked.The hearing follows a Federal Communications Commission proposal to allow consumers to swap pricey cable and other pay TV boxes for cheaper devices and apps
column2: a change that would boost competition in the $20 billion television set-top box market.The proposal would let customers get video services from providers like Alphabet Inc
column3: Apple Inc and Tivo Inc. It set off a lobbying battle between tech companies eager to tap into the market and cable and TV companies which could lose billions of dollars in rental fees.

column1: The FCC says 99 percent of U.S. customers now must get their boxes from their cable companies
column2: and they pay on average $231 a year to lease the devices.Cable companies say the video marketplace is already evolving as more customers replace traditional pay TV services with streaming internet video. (Reporting by David Shepardson; Editing by Bernard Orr and Andrew Hay)"	['Warner']	[]

column1: 6	6	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-congress-fdic-idUSKCN0YV2K7	U.S. representatives question bank regulator on whistleblowers	"

WASHINGTON Leaders of the congressional committee that investigates data breaches and computer hacking blasted the main U.S. banking regulator on Thursday for possibly jeopardizing the work of its inspector general
column2: an internal watchdog
column3: and hunting out potential whistleblowers. Part of the House Science Committee for months has been looking into the theft of thousands of records from the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp
column4: including two breaches in which workers downloaded more than 10
column5: 000 sensitive and private records onto portable storage devices before leaving the agency's employ.In a letter to FDIC Chairman Martin Gruenberg
column9: chairman of the subcommittee on oversight
column10: described an agency slow to cooperate with lawmakers that fails to conduct ""good faith"" searches for requested information.Moreover
column13: said the FDIC had gathered and reviewed internal communications of its inspector general's office while collecting documents that the committee had requested. By law
column14: inspectors general are independent. They function as the ethical and legal consciences of federal agencies
column16: often with information provided confidentially by employees.

column1: Not only is the committee troubled that the FDIC continues to withhold pertinent and responsive information to its cybersecurity posture
column2: it is ""even more concerned by the FDIC's gathering and review"" of the inspector general office's internal communications
column3: they wrote.That could compromise the inspector general's ""ability to conduct its work in a manner uninhibited by the very agency it was created to oversee
column4: they added.The FDIC was not immediately available to comment.

column1: When the committee received documents from the FDIC earlier this week
column2: the lawmakers said
column3: it noticed a ""distinct watermark included on each page."" ""Given the committee's concerns about potential retaliation against whistleblowers discussed in previous letters to the FDIC
column4: the FDIC's inclusion of a novel watermark raises serious questions about whether the agency it attempting to identify the source of committee materials

column1: They added that some of the watermarked pages covered communications between the inspector general and FDIC employees
column2: raising concerns that the agency is attempting to identify confidential informants.The committee is demanding that the FDIC send it information on actions to protect whistleblowers and inspector general communications by Monday
column3: June 13. (Reporting by Lisa Lambert; Editing by Dan Grebler)"	[]	[]

column1: 8	8	http://reuters.com/article/us-michigan-education-idUSKCN0YV2AX	Michigan lawmakers approve Detroit school rescue package	"
Legislation approved by Michigan lawmakers on Thursday to bail out the Detroit Public Schools (DPS) will keep the district operating
column2: but falls short on funding to fix its crumbling buildings
column3: according to school officials.The bill package
column4: approved over objections by Democratic lawmakers
column6: debt-free district governed by an elected school board
column7: while leaving the current district in place solely to levy property taxes to pay off outstanding debt.DPS
column10: has been under state control since 2009 because of a financial emergency.The American Federation of Teachers-Michigan and Detroit Federation of Teachers criticized the lack of a bipartisan compromise in a joint statement on Thursday.""These bills are a statement by non-Detroit Republicans that they know what is best for Detroit
column11: a city that is overwhelmingly people of color
column12: the groups said. ""It has been this attitude that resulted in Detroit Public Schools' massive debt
column13: low academic performance and a 'wild west' system of school openings.""

column1: Under the measures approved on Thursday
column2: Michigan would commit $617 million from the state's share of a tobacco settlement in annual increments of $72 million for the new Detroit Community School District. An emergency state loan for transition costs was capped at $150 million
column3: with only $25 million of that amount available for capital improvements
column4: less than the overall $200 million sought by DPS.""We also look forward to working creatively with the governor's office
column6: and the Michigan Department of Education to identify the remainder of the critical resources necessary to educate our students
column7: DPS state-appointed transition manager Steven Rhodes said in a statement.A smaller bailout passed by the House in May raised concerns that DPS would run out of cash later this summer.

column1: Republican lawmakers contended the final $617 million bailout legislation would prevent DPS from filing for municipal bankruptcy even though Rhodes
column2: a former federal bankruptcy judge
column3: has said such a move would be ineffective because much of the district's debt is guaranteed by the state.Democrats objected to the absence of a Detroit Education Commission to oversee the opening and closing of public and charter schools in Detroit.

column1: The House and Senate approved the package with a series of votes late Wednesday and early Thursday
column2: sending the legislation to the desk of Republican Governor Rick Snyder
column3: who signaled in a statement that he supports it.  (Reporting by Brendan O'Brien in Milwaukee and Karen Pierog in Chicago; Editing by Dominic Evans and Matthew Lewis)"	['Evans']	[]
